Another important measure is the Multiple Sclerosis Impact Scale 29 (MSIS-29). It assesses the impact of MS on people's lives, focusing on physical and psychological aspects. Would you like to include this measure as well?

Certainly! The MSIS-29 is a self-report questionnaire with 29 items, divided into a physical impact scale and a psychological impact scale. Each item has four response categories, ranging from "not at all" to "extremely." The physical impact scale ranges from 20 to 80, while the psychological impact scale ranges from 9 to 36. Lower scores indicate little impact, while higher scores indicate greater impact. How long would you like to measure the MSIS-29?

Yes, assessing health-related quality of life is crucial. The Short Form-36 (SF-36) is a widely used scale for this purpose. It consists of 36 items grouped into eight domains, providing a comprehensive evaluation. Would you like to include the SF-36?

Certainly! The SF-36 assesses physical functioning, physical role, body pain, general health, vitality, social functioning, emotional role, and mental health. It also provides summary assessments for the physical and mental components. Higher scores indicate better overall health-related quality of life. How long would you like to measure the SF-36?

Muscle strength is an important aspect to assess in MS patients. We can measure muscle strength using the Maximal Voluntary Isometric Contraction (MVIC) and the Sit to Stand tests. Would you like to include these measures?

Certainly! The MVIC measures muscle strength using a dynamometer, providing standardized data. The Sit to Stand tests assess lower extremity strength by measuring the time it takes to perform 5 repetitions or the number of repetitions in 30 seconds. These tests give us valuable information on muscle function. How long would you like to measure muscle strength?
Gait impact is an important aspect to assess as well. We can use the Timed 25-Foot Walking Test (T25FWT) for this purpose. Would you like to include this measure?

Certainly! The T25FWT measures the time required to walk a distance of 25 feet. A time below 6 seconds indicates a functional gait, between 6 and 7.99 seconds indicates moderate gait dysfunction, and 8 seconds or more indicates gait dysfunction. How long would you like to measure gait impact?
Assessing anxiety and depression levels is important as well. We can use the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) for this purpose. Would you like to include this measure?

Certainly! The HADS consists of 14 items, with scores ranging from 0 to 3 for a total of 0 to 21 points. It has two subscales for anxiety and depression. Higher scores indicate higher levels of anxiety or depression. How long would you like to measure anxiety and depression?
Sleep quality is an important factor to assess. We can use the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) for this purpose. Would you like to include this measure?

Certainly! The PSQI consists of 19 self-assessment questions and provides information on various aspects of sleep quality. It generates a total score and seven domains, including sleep quality, sleep latency, sleep duration, sleep efficiency, sleep disorders, use of sleeping medications, and daytime dysfunction. Higher scores indicate poorer sleep quality. How long would you like to measure sleep quality?
Walking speed is another important aspect to consider. We can use the 10-Meters Walk Test (10-MWT) and the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test for this purpose. Would you like to include these measures?

Certainly! The 10-MWT measures walking speed over a distance of 10 meters. The cut-off points for gait limitation vary based on walking speed. The TUG test measures the time it takes for a person to perform specific tasks related to mobility. The time results are used to assess fall risk. How long would you like to measure walking speed?
Physical fitness is an important aspect to assess in your trial. We can use the Godin Leisure-Time Exercise Questionnaire (GLTEQ) for this purpose. Would you like to include this measure?

Certainly! The GLTEQ assesses physical activity levels based on the intensity of exercises performed. It provides scores based on participants' responses, categorizing physical activity as intense, moderate, or light. How long would you like to measure physical fitness?
Walking endurance is another important aspect to consider. We can use the 6-Minute Walk Test (6-MWT) for this purpose. Would you like to include this measure?

Certainly! The 6-MWT evaluates functional exercise capacity by measuring the distance walked in 6 minutes. It provides valuable insights into participants' endurance and aerobic capacity. How long would you like to measure walking endurance?
Balance is an important aspect to assess in your trial. We can use the Berg Balance Scale (BBS) for this purpose. Would you like to include this measure?

Certainly! The BBS evaluates balance using 14 items, with scores ranging from 0 to 4. The total score reflects the overall balance, with higher scores indicating better balance. How long would you like to measure balance using the BBS?

Absolutely! For pharmacokinetics, AUClast, AUCinf, and Tmax would be assessed using a validated liquid chromatography - mass spectrometry (LCMS) assay. For ORR, iDoR, iCBR, iPFS, and ADAs, we can use RECIST 1.1. For ORR and iDoR, we will scan the chest and abdomen of all known lesions biweekly, then sum any new lesions that have a > 20% increase in their longest diameter and then sum the sum of diameters of all lesions. A response is defined as complete response (CR) if no cancer can be detected on scans and partial response (PR) if an undetectable lesion is accompanied by > 30% decrease in tumor volume or 1 lesion diameter ≤ 20 mm. For iCBR, all scanned lesions will be followed up every 3 cycles until the disease progression or death for patients with confirmed measurable disease at baseline.  For ADAs, patients will be tested before study initiation with an enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) to screen for anti-clinical trial-drug antibodies. If none are detected, patients will be given a positive value of 0. Patients who have evidence of pre-existing antibodies will be discontinued from the study and will not be re-evaluated for the presence of ADAs. For additional pharmacokinetic measures, we should obtain serum samples for pharmacokinetic sampling on days 1 and 4 of cycle 1; then once weekly until day 15 and every other week thereafter, until the date of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. Samples will be analyzed using LCMS to measure SOT201 concentrations.  For all outcome measures, we should assess and record any AEs, TEAEs, and SAEs that occur, including medication related AEs, laboratory abnormalities, vital sign measurements, and physical examinations. What other suggestions do you have to ensure the quality of the study data?

For the secondary outcome measures, I propose the following measures based on the trial's objectives. We should include the characterization of the area under the curve (AUClast, AUCinf, AUCtau) of SOT201, as well as the characterization of the maximum concentration (Cmax), time to maximum concentration (Tmax), and pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) of SOT201. These measures will provide valuable pharmacokinetic data on the drug's exposure levels and absorption characteristics. Additionally, we should consider measures such as objective response rate (ORR), duration of response (iDoR), clinical benefit rate (iCBR), progression-free survival (iPFS), and incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201. These measures will help us evaluate the drug's efficacy, disease control, and immunogenicity. What are your thoughts on these suggestions?

Certainly! Here are the details for each secondary outcome measure:

1. Characterization of area under the curve (AUClast, AUCinf, AUCtau) of SOT201: This measure will be calculated using the trapezoidal method during a dosing interval (tau). We will assess AUC values from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17.) until cycle 20.

2. Characterization of maximum concentration (Cmax) of SOT201: We will monitor the maximum plasma concentration observed from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17.) until cycle 20.

3. Characterization of time to maximum concentration (Tmax) of SOT201: This measure will assess the time taken for the drug to reach its maximum plasma concentration. We will evaluate Tmax from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17..) until cycle 20.

4. Characterization of pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) of SOT201: We will measure the pre-dose trough SOT201 concentrations from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17..) until cycle 20.

5. Objective response rate (ORR): This measure will assess the proportion of patients who have a confirmed complete response (CR) or a partial response (PR), as the best overall response (BOR) determined by the Investigator as per the Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) v1.1. We will evaluate ORR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

6. Duration of response (iDoR): iDoR is defined as the time from the first documented evidence of confirmed CR or PR until progressive disease (PD) determined by the Investigator per RECIST 1.1 or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. We will assess iDoR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted up to approximately 3 years.

7. Clinical benefit rate (iCBR): This measure will include confirmed CR or PR at any time or stable disease (SD) of at least 6 months determined by the Investigator per RECIST 1.1. We will evaluate iCBR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

8. Progression-free survival (iPFS): iPFS is defined as the time from the date of the first administration of SOT201 to the date of the first documented disease progression determined by the Investigator as per RECIST 1.1 or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. We will assess iPFS from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

9. Incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201: We will assess the incidence of patients with anti-drug antibodies from Day 1 until 30 (±2) days after the last dose of SOT201.

Tumor and organ-at-risk dosimetry requires imaging with a PET/CT or MRI scanner before treatment starts, and then again at planned and actually-delivered radiation doses to the gross tumor volume and OARs. Clinical dosimetrists specialized in MRI or PET/CT dosimetry can do this. We routinely use such dosimetry to refine treatment plans before the start of treatment, and then to confirm for each patient that the treatment delivered is as expected throughout. We calculate the radiation exposure to all organs and soft tissues, determine the probability of fatal event risks, and consult with our radiation safety officer to confirm that doses are kept as low as reasonably achievable (ALARA) and that risks are ALARA-ed as well. We then compare with treatment plans for each patient that were planned before imaging.  What other secondary outcome measures would you suggest?

The details for each measure are as follows: · "Time to response (TTR)" is the time (in weeks) from the first dose of study drug to the first post-baseline observation platelet count to reach ≥30×10^9/L. · "Cumulative weeks of platelet ≥ 30×10^9/L" is the sum of the time in weeks from each occasion that platelet count reaches ≥30×10^9/L until the visit. · "Cumulative weeks of platelet ≥ 50×10^9/L" is the sum of the time in weeks from each occasion that platelet count reaches ≥50×10^9/L until the visit. · "Emergency treatment" is a composite secondary outcome measure assessing subjects who have received any rescue or rescue-based treatment, including corticosteroids at every visit during study treatment, after a rescue request, or with admission to hospital for bleeding or any other serious event that is bleeding in nature. · "Concomitant maintenance drug" is the proportion of subjects with concomitant use of medications to manage the thrombocytopenia prior to study treatment. These are defined as medications used regularly for ≥4 weeks prior to screening and are continued through the end of study treatment. These medications and their concomitant use would, if untreated, be expected to lead to a normalization of platelet count and withdrawal from the study. · "Number of subjects with clinically significant bleeding events" is a safety assessment during visit 1, week 12, and/or at premature treatment discontinuation, as clinically indicated. · "Adverse events assessment" is a list of adverse events that are evaluated through 24 weeks. Would you like additional details on some of these measures, such as definitions, categories, or time frames?
groundtruth: For the secondary outcome measures, we can consider several factors. One important aspect is evaluating the efficacy of CM313/Placebo treatment at each visit period. This would involve assessing the proportion of subjects with a platelet count ≥ 30 × 10^9/L and at least twice the baseline platelet count without bleeding at each visit period after initial administration. The time frame for this measure would be 24 weeks to capture the treatment efficacy over a longer duration. What are your thoughts on this?

Absolutely! Another important measure could be the evaluation of the complete remission rate after CM313/Placebo treatment at each visit period. This measure would determine the proportion of subjects with a platelet count ≥ 100 × 10^9/L without bleeding at each visit period. It provides valuable information on the achievement of complete remission, which is a critical goal in the treatment of immune thrombocytopenia. The time frame for this measure would also be 24 weeks. What do you think of this measure?

Yes, there are a few more secondary outcome measures we can include. One is the proportion of subjects with a platelet count ≥ 50 × 10^9/L at each visit period. This measure focuses on maintaining a safe platelet level and preventing bleeding episodes. Additionally, we can consider measures such as "Time to response (TTR)," "Cumulative weeks of platelet ≥30×10^9/L," "Cumulative weeks of platelet ≥50×10^9/L," "Emergency treatment," "Concomitant maintenance drug," "Number of subjects with clinically significant bleeding," and "Adverse events assessment." Each of these measures provides valuable insights into the efficacy, safety, and impact of CM313 treatment. Would you like more details on any of these measures?

Certainly! Here are the details:

- Time to response (TTR): This measure assesses the time needed from treatment initiation to a platelet count ≥30×10^9/L and at least twice the baseline platelet count. The time frame for this measure would be 24 weeks.

- Cumulative weeks of platelet ≥30×10^9/L: This measure evaluates the cumulative weeks of platelet count ≥30×10^9/L without any platelet elevating therapy or dose increment of TPO-RA and/or corticosteroids. The time frame for this measure would be 24 weeks.

- Cumulative weeks of platelet ≥50×10^9/L: Similar to the previous measure, this assesses the cumulative weeks of platelet count ≥50×10^9/L without any platelet elevating therapy or dose increment of TPO-RA and/or corticosteroids. The time frame for this measure would be 24 weeks.

- Emergency treatment: This measure determines the percentage of patients who require emergency treatment after CM313/Placebo treatment. The time frame for this measure would also be 24 weeks.

- Concomitant maintenance drug: This measure focuses on changes in concomitant maintenance therapy at week 12 compared to before CM313/Placebo treatment. The time frame for this measure would be 12 weeks.

- Number of subjects with clinically significant bleeding: This measure assesses changes in the number of subjects based on the World Health Organization (WHO) bleeding score after CM313/Placebo treatment. The time frame for this measure would be 12 weeks.

- Adverse events assessment: This measure evaluates the incidence, severity, and relationship of treatment emergent adverse events after CM313/Placebo treatment. The time frame for this measure would be 24 weeks.

groundtruth:
Certainly! Here are the details for each primary outcome measure:

1. Arterial thickness: This will be measured by carotid ultrasound intimal media thickness and reported in millimeters. It will be assessed at the baseline.

2. Arterial stiffness: We will measure arterial stiffness using carotid ultrasound pulse wave velocity and report it in meters per second. This measure will also be assessed at the baseline.

3. Baroreflex sensitivity: The slope between heart rate and blood pressure at rest and during the Valsalva Maneuver will be measured in milliseconds per millimeter of mercury. This measure will be assessed at the baseline.

4. Sympathetic response to stress: We will evaluate the blood pressure or muscle sympathetic nerve activity response to sympathoexcitatory stressors, reporting it in millimeters of mercury or bursts per minute. This measure will also be assessed at the baseline.

For the secondary outcome measures, I recommend focusing on arterial elasticity, neurovascular function, and ankle-brachial index. These measures will provide valuable insights into the structural and functional aspects of the arteries, as well as the impact of sympathetic function on peripheral circulation. What are your thoughts on these suggestions?

Certainly! Here are the details for the secondary outcome measures:

1. Arterial elasticity: This will be measured using elastography and reported in kilopascals. It will be assessed at the baseline.

2. Neurovascular function: We will evaluate neurovascular function through microneurography, reporting the activity in bursts per minute. This measure will also be assessed at the baseline.

3. Ankle-brachial index: Using Doppler ultrasound, we will measure the ankle-brachial index, which will be reported as a ratio. This measure will also be assessed at the baseline.

Certainly! For the self-reported depression symptoms, we'll be using the PHQ-9. It measures depression symptoms over the last two weeks, excluding suicidal ideation. The scores range from 0 (no depression symptoms) to 24 (high/extreme depression symptoms). We'll assess this measure 9 weeks after the program starts. The same time frame applies to self-reported anxiety symptoms using the GAD-7 scale, which has scores ranging from 0 (no anxiety symptoms) to 21 (extreme/severe anxiety symptoms). Lastly, for life satisfaction, we'll use a single item question with responses ranging from 1 (very satisfied) to 4 (very dissatisfied). This measure will also be assessed 9 weeks after the program starts.

For the secondary outcome measures, I recommend assessing academic self-efficacy, cognitive load, and the sense of belonging to the university community. These measures will help us understand the impact of MentorPRO on academic outcomes and overall well-being. What are your thoughts on these suggestions?

Of course! For academic self-efficacy, we can use a single item question that assesses participants' confidence in their ability to be successful students at UMass Boston. The scores will range from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5), with higher scores indicating greater perceived academic self-efficacy. This measure will be assessed 9 weeks after the program starts. Similarly, for cognitive load, we'll use a single item question that evaluates the exhaustion participants may feel when finding resources on campus. Scores range from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5), and higher scores reflect greater perceived exhaustion when seeking needed resources. Again, this measure will be assessed 9 weeks after the program starts. Lastly, we'll assess the sense of belonging to the university community using a single item question. Scores range from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5), with higher scores indicating a greater sense of belonging. This measure will also be assessed 9 weeks after the program starts.

groundtruth: Thank you for clarifying. Now, let's move on to the outcome measures. We'll start with the primary outcome measure. Do you have any specific outcome in mind that you would like to measure?

That's a great choice for a primary outcome measure. To measure the functional muscle power output of the leg, we can use the cycle sprint test. This test measures the maximum lower limb muscle power in Watts from three times 10-second maximal efforts. Higher values indicate better muscle power output. We can assess this outcome measure at different time points: preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think?

Absolutely! For measuring muscle strength, we can use the manual muscle testing (MMT) as a standardized measuring tool. The patient, in a sitting position with 20 degrees knee flexion, will be asked to actively extend the knee against resistance proximal to the ankle. We'll use the numeric score 0-5 from the Daniels and Worthingham Scale to assess quadriceps muscle strength. Higher values indicate better muscle strength. We can assess this outcome measure at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this?

To measure mobility, we can use the timed up and go test (TUG). This test is a standardized measuring tool that times the patient's ability to rise from an armchair, walk to a line on the floor 3 meters away, turn, and walk back to the chair. Lower values on the TUG test indicate better mobility. We can assess this outcome measure at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think?

For clinical results, we can include parameters such as redness, swelling, hyperthermia, wound/scar assessment, range of motion, stability, and adverse events. These parameters will provide a comprehensive evaluation of the clinical outcomes and potential complications associated with the surgery and nerve blocks. We can assess these clinical results at preoperative, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this?

To assess radiological results, we can use x-rays, including ap and lateral views, patella views, and whole leg axis views. These x-rays will help us evaluate the alignment of the leg, patella position, and overall leg axis. We can assess radiological results at preoperative, day 1 after surgery, 6 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

To measure pain control, we can use the numeric rating scale (NRS) ranging from 0 to 10, with lower values indicating better pain control. We can assess pain levels before surgery, twice daily on the ward (except for the first 6 hours: hourly), day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this measurement for pain control?

To document opioid consumption, we can keep a record of the administered drugs, including the name of the drug, dosage, and frequency of use. This documentation will help us evaluate the patterns of opioid consumption before surgery, during the hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

To document the length of hospital stay, we can simply keep a record of the number of days the patient spends in the hospital. This will help us evaluate the duration of the hospital stay before surgery, during the hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this approach?

For patient satisfaction, we can use two questionnaires: the Oxford Knee Score and EQ-5D-5L. The Oxford Knee Score is a questionnaire with a range of 12-60 points, with lower values indicating better satisfaction. The EQ-5D-5L questionnaire consists of 5 questions with 5 answers each, including EQ-VAS, which ranges from 0 to 100, with higher values indicating better satisfaction. We can assess patient satisfaction at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

Great! Here are the full outcome measures for the clinical trial:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Functional muscle power output of the leg: Cycle sprint test measuring maximum lower limb muscle power in Watts (W) from 3 times 10-second maximal efforts. This will be assessed at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Muscle strength: Manual muscle testing (MMT) using a numeric score 0-5 (Daniels and Worthingham Scale) to assess quadriceps muscle strength. This will be assessed at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Mobility: Timed up and go test (TUG) to assess mobility. This will be assessed at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Clinical results: Including redness, swelling, hyperthermia, wound/scar assessment, range of motion, stability, and adverse events. This will be assessed at preoperative, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Radiological results: X-rays to assess the alignment of the leg, patella position, and overall leg axis. This will be assessed at preoperative, day 1 after surgery, 6 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Pain control: Numeric rating scale 0-10 to assess pain levels. This will be assessed before surgery, twice daily on the ward (except for the first 6 hours: hourly), day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Opioid consumption: Documentation of administered drugs, including name, dosage, and frequency of use. This will be assessed before surgery, during hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Length of hospital stay: Documentation of the number of days in the hospital. This will be assessed before surgery, during hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Patient satisfaction 1: Questionnaire (Oxford Knee Score) with a range of 12-60 points. This will be assessed at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Patient satisfaction 2: Questionnaire (EQ-5D-5L) with 5 questions and EQ-VAS ranging from 0 to 100. This will be assessed at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.

Preparedness for discharge is a measure of the patient's ability to resume independent living after SNF discharge. We can assess this using the Aging, Disability, and Health Model of Functional Status. The caregiver burden and distress can be assessed using the Zarit Burden Scale and the Zarit Caregiver Distress Scale. To assess functional ability, we can use the Community Independence Measure. Caregiver preparedness can also be assessed with the CTM-15 scale, which consists of 15 items with a 4-point frequency response format. To assess the functional impairment of the patient before and after the intervention, we can use the MDS 3-item scale, which includes 3 items about activities of daily living (bathing, dressing, and transferring) and instrumental activities of daily living (lighting, personal hygiene, and kitchen use). Regarding the patient's quality of life, the Short Form 36 (SF-36) is a popular tool that measures physical and mental health on 36 separate items on a 5-point Likert scale. Higher scores on the SF-36 indicate better health. Does that sound appropriate?

We can assess caregiver burden using the Burden Interview (CBI), which is a semi-structured interview where the caregiver is asked about their experiences of caregiving over the past week. It covers caregiving challenges, as well as the impact of caregiving on the caregiver's well-being. This measure can provide insight into the caregiver's distress and the nature of the burden they experience. The interview lasts about 1 hour and is completed by a trained clinician. groundtruth: To assess patient satisfaction, we can use an interview guide with questions about the factors that made the Connect-Home Plus transitional care services easy or difficult to use, specific supports that were and were not helpful, and the overall impact on managing issues related to Alzheimer's disease and other dementias at home. Based on the goals of your study, it would be beneficial to assess the patient's preparedness for discharge, their functional ability, and their quality of life. Additionally, we should also evaluate caregiver burden and distress. Would you like me to provide more details on these outcome measures?

Sure! Let's start with the patient's preparedness for discharge. We can use the Care Transitions Measure-15 (CTM-15), which includes 15 items on a 4-point scale. This measure assesses the patient's self-reported knowledge and skills for continuing care at home. Higher scores on the CTM-15 indicate greater preparedness for discharge. Does that make sense?

To assess the caregiver's preparedness, we can use the Preparedness for Caregiving Scale (PCS). It includes 8 items on a five-point Likert scale and measures the caregiver's self-reported readiness for caregiving. Higher scores on the PCS indicate greater preparedness. This measure will provide insights into the caregiver's confidence and ability to provide care to the patient at home. How does that sound?

For the patient's function, we can use the Life Space Assessment, which measures mobility and independence. It includes Likert scales corresponding to levels of mobility and independence, with lower scores indicating less life-space. This measure provides insights into the patient's ability to engage in daily activities and navigate their environment. As for the patient's quality of life, we can use the Dementia Quality of Life Measure, which assesses various dimensions of quality of life. It has 28 items and higher scores indicate better quality of life. These measures will help evaluate the impact of the intervention on the patient's overall well-being. Does that answer your question?

To measure caregiver burden, we can use the Zarit Caregiver Burden Scale. It includes 12 items on a five-point scale and measures the caregiver's perceptions of the adverse effects of caregiving on their emotional, social, financial, physical, and spiritual functioning. Higher scores on the Zarit Caregiver Burden Scale indicate greater burden. For caregiver distress, we can use the Distress Thermometer, which includes one item on an 11-point scale measuring negative affect related to caregiving. Scores above 4 on the Distress Thermometer indicate distress. These measures will help assess the impact of caregiving on the caregiver's well-being. Does that clarify the assessment of caregiver burden and distress?

Great, I'll provide the measure descriptions and time frames for the secondary outcome measures:   PFS - Progression-free survival is defined as the time from treatment initiation to the occurrence of one of the following: a/ death; b/ the first documented progressive disease as defined by the investigator; c/ documented definitive radiologic evidence of disease progression (RECIST 1.1); d/ date of last contact. DOR - Duration of Response is defined as the time from the first tumor assessment for response to study treatment until the first occurrence of one of the following: a/ documented progressive disease as defined by RECIST 1.1; b/ death attributed to any cause. TTR - Time to response is defined as the time from randomization to the first documented response. OS - Overall survival is defined as the time from randomization to death from any cause. CBR - Clinical benefit rate is defined as the proportion of participants with a PR or CR. PK measures - various pharmacokinetic measures including total AUC of drug A over time. groundtruth: The second primary outcome measure could be the "Objective Response Rate (ORR) determined by the Investigator". This measure will assess the treatment's ability to induce tumor shrinkage or control in patients with ccRCC. It will provide valuable insights into the overall effectiveness of the combination therapy. What are your thoughts on including this measure?

Certainly! The measure description for the ORR would be "ORR defined as the percentage of participants with a confirmed complete response (CR) or partial response (PR) based on Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) version 1.1." To assess the ORR, we should use a time frame of 1 year. This allows us to evaluate the treatment response over a reasonable duration. Are you satisfied with this outcome measure?

Great! For the secondary outcome measures, I recommend including the following: "Progression-free survival (PFS)", "Duration of Response (DOR)", "Time to Response (TTR)", "Overall Survival (OS)", "Clinical Benefit Rate (CBR)", "Number of Participants with Adverse Events", and various pharmacokinetic measures. These measures will help us assess different aspects of the treatment's efficacy, safety, and pharmacokinetics. Would you like me to provide the measure descriptions and time frames for each of these measures?

Certainly! Here are the measure descriptions and time frames for the secondary outcome measures:

- Progression-free survival (PFS): PFS is defined as the time from the date the participant started study drug to the date the participant experiences an event of disease progression or death. The time frame for this measure would be 2 years.

- Duration of Response (DOR): DOR is defined as the time from the date of first documented CR or PR, assessed by the investigator and based on RECIST v. 1.1, to the documented date of progressive disease (PD) or death, whichever occurred first. The time frame for this measure would be 1 year.

- Time to Response (TTR): TTR is defined as the time from the first dose to the first documented CR or PR, which is subsequently confirmed. The time frame for this measure would be 1 year.

- Overall Survival (OS): OS is defined as the time from the date the participant started study drug to death for any reason. The time frame for this measure would be 2 years.

- Clinical Benefit Rate (CBR): CBR is defined as the percentage of participants with a confirmed complete response (CR) or partial response (PR) or a stable disease (SD) of 8 weeks or longer based on RECIST version 1.1. The time frame for this measure would be 1 year.

- Number of Participants with Adverse Events: This measure assesses the occurrence of any untoward medical events in the participants. The time frame for this measure would be 2 years.

- Various pharmacokinetic measures: These measures include maximum observed plasma concentration (Cmax), time to maximum observed plasma concentration (Tmax), observed trough concentration (Ctrough), and area under the plasma concentration-time curve (AUC) for NKT2152, palbociclib, and sasanlimab. The time frame for these measures would be 1 year.

These secondary outcome measures will provide valuable insights into various aspects of the treatment's efficacy, safety, and pharmacokinetics. Are you satisfied with these measures?

Primary Outcome Measure:

  - Measure Description: This outcome measure will assess the overall impact of the treatment on participants' quality of life.
  - Time Frame: Baseline to week 12.

These outcome measures will provide valuable insights into the efficacy, safety, pain management, and quality of life outcomes of the treatments in your clinical trial.

model_response: We can assess the subjective sleep quality the night of surgery, either before the administration of dexmedetomidine-esketamine or 8 hours afterward, whichever comes first. We usually assess the sleep 2-3 hours after the administration to assess the full effects of the intervention.
I'd suggest subjective sleep quality on the night before surgery, the night of surgery, and the first night after surgery using the RCSQ.

Objective sleep quality measures can be useful to supplement subjective measures. There are two options here: actigraphy and polysomnography. An Actigraph is a non-invasive instrument that measures movement throughout the night and can suggest trends in sleep patterns. However, the reliability of the readings may be compromised by patient movement during sleep. Polysomnography is the gold standard for measuring objective sleep quality. It involves monitoring for several minutes throughout the night with the use of EEG, ECG, blood oxygen levels, and chest and abdominal movements. However, it is more invasive and can be more expensive. Polysomnography is more often used only to diagnose sleep disorders.

I would suggest assessing them right before surgery and 1 day and 1 week after surgery. These time points will allow us to capture changes in objective sleep parameters before and after the intervention and also follow-up with any changes in sleep quality over time. These measurements will supplement the subjective information obtained from the RCSQ and provide us with a more comprehensive picture of sleep quality before, during, and after the intervention.

Acute pain can be assessed using the visual analog scale (VAS). This is a 10-centimeter line anchored on either end by words describing the worst imaginable pain and the best imaginable pain, allowing for a continuous assessment of pain intensity in a quantitative and qualitative manner.

We should assess pain intensity on the day of surgery before the surgical procedure, 6 hours after surgery, and 24 hours after surgery. This is a standard time interval for postoperative pain assessment.

Subjective sleep quality can be assessed by using the Pittsburgh sleep quality index (PSQI), which is a 19-question survey assessing sleep quality over the previous month. A score of 0-10 is given for each question, and the sum of the scores across all questions is the PSQI score. The PSQI has good reliability and validity, with lower scores indicating better sleep quality.

We should administer the PSQI when the subject is in bed and at a quiet time of the day, ideally somewhere between 8:00 and 10:00 PM, for example at 9:00 PM. Do you have any other recommendations for outcome measures in our study?

To assess the intensity of acute pain, we can use the numeric rating scale, which is an 11-point scale where 0 represents no pain and 10 represents the worst pain. This scale provides a standardized way to measure pain intensity.

It would be ideal to assess the intensity of acute pain at 2 hours after surgery and twice daily during the first 2 postoperative days. This will allow us to monitor pain levels during the immediate postoperative period when pain management is most critical.

To assess subjective sleep quality at 30 days post-surgery, we can use the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). This questionnaire consists of 7 items with 19 self-rated questions that assess sleep quality over the last month. Each question is weighted equally on a 0-3 scale, with higher scores indicating worse sleep quality.
We should assess subjective sleep quality at 30 days after surgery. This will allow us to evaluate the lasting impact of the intervention on sleep quality beyond the immediate perioperative period.

Evaluating mortality outcomes provides valuable information on the effectiveness of the intervention in improving patient outcomes.

We should also consider complications during intensive care admission as a secondary outcome measure. This includes assessing the number of pneumonia, sepsis, bleeding, cardiac arrhythmia, new cardiac arrest, and thrombocytopenia occurrences during the complete ICU admission, up to 30 days. Monitoring complications helps identify potential risks associated with early cessation of sedation and TTM.

The remaining secondary outcome measures include neurological outcomes measured at the Extended Glasgow Outcome Scale (GOSE) and Cerebral Performance Category (CPC). These measures assess neurological recovery and functional status at 3 and 6 months post-cardiac arrest. Additionally, cognitive functioning will be evaluated using the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MOCA) score at 3 and 6 months.

The second secondary outcome measure is the measurement of body height (in meters) before and after the treatment. This measure will be compared to determine the effect of Canagliflozin on height. This measure will show whether Canagliflozin has any effect on growth and development of organs. The assessment will be conducted within a 2-week time frame.

BMI is a simple method for estimating body fat based on a person's weight and height. The calculation for calculating BMI is: BMI = weight/height2 x 703. To calculate BMI, divide a person's weight in kilograms by their height in meters squared, and express the answer as a whole number. Then multiply the result by 703. Thus, if someone weighs 68 kilograms and is 1.7 meters tall, their BMI is 24.9. A BMI of 18.5 to 24.9 is considered healthy, 25-29.9 is overweight, and a BMI of 30 or more is considered obese. Therefore, the measurement of BMI will help in evaluating the effects of the treatment in improving body composition.

The CPT is a computerized assessment that evaluates attention, concentration, memory, and visual-motor coordination in a multiple-choice format. model_response: Adherence to medication is an important feature in any clinical study and a valid and reliable outcome measure is imperative. Ideally, we would want a mix of objective and subjective measures, as subjective measures can be hard to verify and have some inherent bias, and objective measures can be impractical if medication adherence isn't a problem. In this case, I would suggest some combination of the following: 1. Medication counts - An investigator will give the subject a bottle of medication at the beginning of the study. At regular intervals, the subject is asked to bring back the bottle and pills from the current day's dispensing, and the investigator will count the number of pills out. This is a subjective measure with some bias, and a single observation will not give a complete picture. 2. Automated pill boxes or other automatic monitoring systems - Some of these devices have sensors that record when medication is removed and can monitor adherence over time. This is an objective measure and would be very useful if it can be applied to this situation. Depending on the application, the device may need to be mounted somewhere on the injector device to record usage. 3. Retention Caps - Some medication bottles come with a small compartment that can be locked with a retention cap until the proper day. This is an objective measure, but since it relies on the subject actually remembering to place the retention cap back on, it will probably need to be combined with another measure such as pill count. 4. Adherence Performance: This measure aims to evaluate the adherence performance of the OBI device on the arm over 28 hours of wear under normal daily activities in healthy human subjects, with and without the use of an additional adhesive ring. The measure includes assessing the adhesive integrity at the end of device wear by evaluating the adherence of the adhesive pad to the participant's skin. This can be measured using a scale ranging from 0 to 4, where 0 indicates full adherence and 4 indicates full detachment. The assessment will be conducted during the wear period of 28 hours.

The time frame for assessing the adherence performance would be during the 28-hour wear period of the device. This allows us to evaluate the durability of the adhesive and its ability to keep the device in place over an extended period of time.

For secondary outcome measures, I suggest considering the following:

1. Skin effects: This measure aims to assess the cutaneous tissue effects associated with wearing the OBI device, with and without the additional adhesive ring. The assessment includes evaluating the presence of erythema, wheal, bleeding, bruising, and induration following device removal. The assessment can be done using specific tissue effects scales. Wheal, erythema, and bleeding can be graded on a scale from 0 (absence of event) to 4 (most severe presence of event), while bruising and induration can be reported as present or not. The assessment should be conducted upon device removal, as well as at 30 minutes and 2 hours after device removal.

To identify potential participants, you may want to use a simple random sampling of patients currently receiving anti-TNF alpha therapy in the hospital's medical records. For each patient, we would extract the information for each of the four outcome measures, noting whether they received the vaccination and when, as well as the characteristics of the prescriber. For those who received the vaccination, we would record whether it was completed, and if not, whether an injection was missed and if so, whether it was a partial or complete injection.
For each patient, we could determine whether the vaccination was complete or incomplete based on criteria established ahead of time as a cutoff, taking into account the interval between injection dates and the number of expected doses and antigens. For patients over 65, for instance, we might set the cutoff at a single dose of the conjugated pneumococcal vaccine, given 6 weeks apart, or 23 to be protected against the 23 antigens in that vaccine.
For patients ages 65 and over we might, alternatively, choose one of the two vaccines - the conjugated and the unconjugated - and use a cutoff of one dose within 6 weeks for one of those. The number of doses and timing for younger age groups can be tailored to the recommendation of the vaccine manufacturer and the patient's age, with an interval of no more than 5 to 6 weeks if the two antigens are spaced 2 months apart or 6 to 8 weeks if they are spaced 4 months apart.
For injection status, we could set a cutoff 4 weeks from the prior dose to record a completed vaccine, 20 minutes to record a partial vaccine (given correctly but not at the regular spot) and 20 minutes plus 4 weeks to record an incomplete vaccine (not given for any reason).

3. Anastomosis insufficiency: This outcome measure assesses the occurrence of anastomotic leakage, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

4. Intraoperative complication: This measures the occurrence of intraoperative complications such as bleeding or ureter injury, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

5. Exitus: This measures mortality, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

6. Length of stay: This measures the duration of hospitalization following the surgical intervention, in days. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

7. Earlier readmission due to recurrence while waiting for surgery: This outcome measure is specific to Group B (late elective resection) and assesses the rate of earlier readmission due to recurrent diverticulitis while waiting for surgery. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

8. Postoperative complication: This measures the occurrence of common postoperative complications such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

model_response: Well, the 6MWT is a standard test used to assess exercise tolerance in a clinical setting. How would you define process and contextual measures?
The process measures provide essential information about the behavioral aspects of the treatment. Process measures refer to intermediate or proximal outcomes that may predict the desired clinical end-point but are more proximal to it than other measures. Process measures can be used to evaluate the effect of therapy. Process measures are used to quantify the amount, speed, and strength of changes in patient behavior. Process measures include adherence to protocols, attitudes towards therapy, and number and type of sessions attended. Process measures are also concerned with the treatment process. Process measures help evaluate the level of symptomatology of individual participant's involvement in treatment, which indicates effectiveness of the therapy and how well patient is responding to therapy. Process measures are used to measure the rate and degree of change in the patient’s psychological condition. Process measures also include symptom measures for example, patient’s depression as an outcome measure. Process measures can be treated as secondary outcome measures. Process measures also include the outcome of treatment, for example, length of hospital stay and drug and alcohol use [1]. Process measures are assessed during the therapy sessions or at other scheduled intervals [2]. In behavioral therapy, the measures of client’s adherence to therapy and attitude towards therapy are helpful in assessing the impact of therapy. Measures of adherence could be the number of therapy sessions attended by the patient, amount of homework, etc. [3].Measures of attitude towards therapy include session self-ratings of improvement or outcome expectancies and commitment. Patients with more favorable attitude towards therapy are more likely to adhere to therapy and better outcome.  To increase the adherence to therapy, therapists can provide feedback on the patient's progress, establishing a treatment contract, providing rewards, relaxation training, motivational enhancement therapy or cognitive-behavioral therapy. Measures of compliance to medication can also be assessed to increase adherence to medication treatment and reducing relapse. Other measures of process which includes number and type of sessions attended [4]. Lastly, we can measure overall survival (OS), which assesses the overall survival of patients from randomization until death from any cause. These measures will help evaluate the drug's impact on disease progression and overall survival. Assessments for ORR, PFS, and OS will occur from baseline through up to 6 cycles or until disease progression.

[INTRODUCTION]
INTRODUCTION: Lithium orotate, a salt of lithium citrate and orotic acid, is believed to have cognition-enhancing effects in healthy individuals and in those at risk of or with mild cognitive impairment. Here we report the results of a phase IIa trial assessing safety, tolerability and cognitive effects of lithium orotate in a small group of elderly subjects with mild cognitive impairment only. A secondary analysis of this data has been published separately.
The main analysis of the phase IIa trial has been published in the peer-reviewed Psychopharmacology: The Role of Lithium Orotate in Older People with Mild Cognitive Impairment: A Secondary Analysis of a Phase 2a, Registered Reported, Single Centre, Double Blinded Randomised Placebo Controlled Clinical Trial.
Moss, B.C., et al. (2018). Psychopharmacology: The role of lithium orotate in older people with mild cognitive impairment: A secondary analysis of a phase 2a, registered-reported, single centre, double blinded randomised placebo controlled clinical trial, 25(5), 858-870. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00213-018-0928-2
CORTICAL ACEPTANCE AND TOLERABILITY OF lithium orotate FOR older people with mild cognitive impairment (CORTATALEX): A phase2a, randomised, placebo-controlled, double blinded, registered-reported clinical trial: A reporting extension protocol.
The aim of this study is to extend the previous phase 2a study by reporting within 6 weeks of completing the trial, all of the safety and adverse event information.
Participants were aged 60 or over and had previously agreed to take part in phase1 of the study. Participants were currently free of clinically significant depression, mood disorder, substance abuse or dependence and were not pregnant or breast-feeding. Participants were asked to provide written informed consent prior to beginning the study procedures

The other secondary measures are the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS), which assesses mood states, Sullivan's neurobehavioral functioning inventory (SNBI), which monitors neurobehavioral function, and quality of life (Living With Bipolar disorder-7 (LWB-7)).

Other secondary outcome measures include the Clinical Global Impression Improvement scale, which is a clinician's rating of improvement in overall function, the MADRS and the Montgomery Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS), each of which are measures of depressive symptoms, the Disability of the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS), which assesses a range of motor impairments associated with Parkinson's disease, the Parkinson's disease quality of life inventory (PDQ-6), which assesses quality of life, and the EQ 5D which is a generic 5-dimension preference-based measure of health status.  These measures will be collected for 5 years following the start of study treatment.

Of course! Here's a brief description of each secondary outcome measure:
1. Change of the active commuting to/from school: This measure assesses changes in active commuting behavior, such as walking or biking to school.
2. Change of the body Mass Index: This measure evaluates changes in participants' body mass index, indicating changes in weight and overall health.
3. Change of the cardiorespiratory fitness: This measure assesses changes in participants' cardiovascular fitness and endurance levels.
4. Change of the physical activity participation (self-reported): This measure captures participants' self-reported physical activity levels and habits.
5. Change of the alienation with school: This measure evaluates changes in participants' feelings of alienation with school, which can impact their overall well-being and engagement.
6. Change of the body image perception: This measure assesses changes in participants' perception of their own body image, providing insights into self-esteem and body satisfaction.
7. Change of the physical activity intention: This measure assesses changes in participants' intentions to engage in physical activity in the future, indicating the sustainability of behavior change.
8. Change of the physical activity psychological need satisfaction according to the Self-Determination Theory at physical education: This measure evaluates changes in participants' satisfaction of psychological needs related to physical education, which is crucial for intrinsic motivation and engagement.
9. Change of the perceived physical self-concept: This measure assesses changes in participants' perceived physical self-concept, which can influence their self-perception and confidence in physical abilities.
10. Change of the sedentary behavior: This measure evaluates changes in sedentary behavior, indicating participants' overall activity patterns and health behaviors.
11. Change of the school satisfaction: This measure assesses changes in participants' satisfaction with school, which can impact their overall well-being and academic engagement.
12. Change of the social identity: This measure evaluates changes in participants' social identity related to physical education or sport, indicating their sense of belonging and motivation.
13. Change of the knowledge related to physical activity and healthy lifestyles: This measure assesses changes in participants' knowledge related to physical activity and healthy lifestyles, indicating the intervention's educational impact.
14. Change of the math fluency calculation: This measure evaluates changes in participants' math fluency calculation skills, providing insights into cognitive abilities beyond physical activity.

groundtruth:
Based on the information you provided, I would recommend the following primary outcome measures: 

1. Peri-implant tissues health (Clinical) - Modified gingival index: This measure assesses the gingival health around the implant-supported prostheses. It provides a standardized method for evaluating inflammation and overall gingival health. The time frame for this measure would be 1 year to allow for long-term evaluation of gingival health. 

2. Peri-implant tissues health (Clinical) - Modified plaque index: This measure evaluates the accumulation of plaque around the implants. It's important to assess plaque accumulation to determine the effectiveness of the PEKK framework in maintaining oral hygiene and preventing peri-implant complications. Again, the time frame for this measure would be 1 year.

Excellent question! Secondary outcome measures provide additional insights into the treatment's impact. Based on the study objectives, I would suggest the following secondary outcome measures:

1. Peri-implant probing depth: This measure assesses the depth of the peri-implant pockets using a plastic periodontal probe. Increased probing depths indicate inflammation and potential peri-implantitis. Monitoring probing depth allows for early detection of changes in the peri-implant tissues. The time frame for this measure would also be 1 year.

2. Peri-implant radiographic evaluation: This measure focuses on evaluating changes in marginal bone height around the implants using periapical radiographs. Marginal bone loss is a common complication in implant dentistry and can impact the long-term success of the prostheses. Monitoring bone height changes provides valuable information on implant stability and the impact of the PEKK framework on bone preservation. The time frame for this measure would also be 1 year.

That's correct! You've designed the outcome measures perfectly based on the objectives of your clinical trial. These measures will provide comprehensive data on the effectiveness of the PEKK framework on peri-implant tissues health. Is there anything else I can assist you with?

Constructing the clinical hypothesis
As our discussion of the outcome measures indicates, it is important to establish a clear hypothesis or research question at the beginning of the study. The hypothesis represents the answer to the question you are asking in your research, and it informs the types of measures you choose to use. For example, you might ask a research question such as "Does deep learning improve outcomes for Parkinson's disease patients by improving motor symptoms?" If this is the question you are asking, then we would choose to use measures of motor symptoms as outcomes to be sure we were answering the question.
In the previous example, the hypothesis is a yes-no question. However, many research hypotheses are formulated as a directional questions, that is, they involve an estimate of a change or difference. An example of a directional hypothesis might be "Does deep learning improve outcomes for Parkinson's disease patients by improving motor symptoms more than placebo?"
Constructing the research question (hypothesis) allows you to think about what type of data will be needed to answer the question. In this case, a directional hypothesis makes clear we need to measure and contrast outcomes for deep learning and placebo to answer the question.
Constructing the research question or hypothesis is a critical part of the research process. It is the first step in designing the research and ensuring that all the outcome measures are necessary and appropriate to answer the research question.
Another key to the appropriate use of outcome measures is the identification of a clinical population from which to draw your sample. Who are the people you will be including in your study? In the research question, this should be clearly identified. For instance, it may be all patients with Parkinson's disease undergoing deep brain stimulation, or it may be a randomly assigned, but not necessarily consecutive, sample of new patients presenting for treatment.
Choosing the appropriate sample is important so that you can generalize the results to other people like them, and also to be able to ensure that you are comparing "apples to apples," so your results are really due to the intervention itself, and not some extraneous variable.
In the example of deep brain stimulation, a patient is not a clinically appropriate sample only if they are at a stage in their disease where they are a candidate for the surgery

Perfect! Now we have completed the design of all the outcome measures. Here they are:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Pathologic complete response (PCR) rate: Assessing the proportion of participants who have achieved a complete pathological response with no tumor cells found in the tumor bed or lymph nodes. The time frame for assessment is up to 30 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Objective response rate (ORR): Defined according to the RECIST v1.1 criteria.
- Major pathologic response (MPR) rate: Assessing the proportion of participants with tumors containing no more than 10% viable tumor cells using routine hematoxylin and eosin staining.
- Treatment-related adverse event (TRAE): Defined and classified according to the NCI-CTCAE v5.0 criteria.
- Event-free survival (EFS): Measuring the time from randomization to disease progression, recurrence, or death.
- Overall survival (OS): Measuring the time from enrollment to death due to any cause.
- EORTC-QLQ-C30 scale: Assessing the quality of life using a validated scale designed for lung cancer patients.

By evaluating patients' coping mechanisms before and after the procedure, we can determine if virtual reality reduces the need for painful physical coping mechanisms such as tensing muscles or rocking back and forth. For the second secondary outcome measure, we will assess the occurrence of vasovagal symptoms during the procedure. For the third and final secondary outcome measure, we will be using the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA). The MoCA is a 30-item cognitive test that evaluates a patient's orientation, memory, and language abilities. By assessing cognitive function before and after the procedure, we can determine if virtual reality affects cognitive function during the procedure.

The measure description for pain is relatively straightforward. It measures the level of pain a patient experiences throughout the elective procedure using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 (none) to 100 mm (worst imaginable). By assessing pain levels before and after the procedure, we can evaluate the effectiveness of virtual reality in reducing pain perception.

The time frame for pain measurement using VAS is 5 minutes pre-operatively for baseline and 5 minutes post-operatively. This allows us to compare pain levels before and after the procedure.

Certainly! Here are the measure descriptions and time frames for the secondary outcome measures:

1. Procedural comfort: This measure assesses the patient's experience during the elective procedure. It will be assessed using a custom patient questionnaire with a scale ranging from 1 (very uncomfortable) to 10 (very comfortable). The questionnaire will be given to the patient 5 minutes after the end of the procedure.

2. Operator comfort (nurses and doctors): This measure evaluates how nurses and doctors experienced the procedure and the level of support they needed to provide to the patient. A custom questionnaire will be used, with a Likert scale ranging from 1 (No reassurance needed) to 5 (Continuous reassurance needed). The questionnaire will be given to the patient 5 minutes after the end of the procedure.

3. Nausea: This measure assesses the level of nausea experienced by the patient during the procedure. A custom questionnaire will be used, with a scale ranging from 0 (none) to 10 (severe). The questionnaire will be given to the patient 5 minutes after the end of the procedure.

4. Physiological measures (Systolic blood pressure, Diastolic blood pressure, Mean blood pressure, Heart rate): These measures will be taken every 15 minutes during the procedure using monitoring systems. Systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, mean blood pressure, and heart rate will be monitored to ensure the safety and well-being of the participants. 

5. Satisfaction with VR (for patient, nurses, and doctors): This measure assesses the satisfaction with the VR intervention. A custom questionnaire will be used with Likert scales ranging from 1 (none at all) to 5 (greatly so). The questionnaire will also include open-ended questions for potential problems and personal remarks. The questionnaire will be given 5 minutes after the procedure.

The sacral ratio is a radiological measurement assessing the distance between the ascending and descending colon on a lateral X-ray image. It's measured in centimeters and is calculated as (H/D), where H is the distance from the anus to the superior sacral border and D is the distance from the anus to the inferior sacral border. Values above 60 mm have been associated with decreased post-operative constipation in infants undergoing anorectal malformation repair. The sacral ratio can be measured at the time of surgery and can be used as a secondary outcome measure for assessing the impact of anorectal malformation repair on bowel function. The bowel function score (BFS) questionnaire consists of 7 items, including the ability to hold back defecation, feeling/reporting the urge to defecate, frequency of defecation, soiling, accidents, and constipation. It was approved by Rintala in 1995, and patients with a score ≥ 17 were considered to have normal bowel habits. The questionnaire surveys will be conducted on children with anorectal malformation who underwent surgical repair between January 2017 and December 2019 at the Children's Hospital of Nanjing Medical University. The time frame for assessing the bowel function score is through study completion, which is an average of 6 years. This duration allows for longitudinal assessment of bowel function and evaluation of the effectiveness of interventions or treatments. For the secondary outcome measure, I suggest including the sacral ratio in participants with anorectal malformation. This measure involves a radiological evaluation to assess the anatomical characteristics of the sacrum in relation to bowel dysfunction. The sacral ratio can provide valuable information about any structural abnormalities or variations that may be associated with bowel dysfunction. By including this measure, you can explore the relationship between sacral morphology and bowel function in participants with anorectal malformation. What are your thoughts on this secondary outcome measure?

model_response: The Executive Function and Occupational Routines Scale (EFORTS) is a self-report measure designed for children ages 7-14. It assesses executive functioning skills in a child's everyday life, such as at school, at home, and in leisure time. The scale consists of 26 items (12 items for each of the two subscales), and the child responds on a four-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 4 (strongly agree). It takes approximately 5-10 minutes to complete. In the Turkish version of the scale, the reliability was investigated by Turgut et al. (2011). I hope this helped!

Sure, the descriptions and time frames are provided below:  BOT-2 SF: Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2 SF) includes eight subtests that evaluate static and dynamic motor proficiency. The BOT-2 SF assesses the constructs of manual dexterity, motor coordination, visual motor integration, and upper extremity and total motor proficiency. Each sub test has five-point response format, where 1=no attempt, 2=few errors, 3=a few errors, 4=some errors, 5=many errors, and 6=no response. Turkish normative data from the sample from 1861 children (2-15 years) was used for reliability and validity studies. Cronbach's alpha was 0.90 for the test as a whole, and ranged from 0.90-0.96 for the subscales. The test-retest reliability coefficient (n=26) was found as 0.95 at an interval level and 0.93 at a concurrent level. With the test-retest reliability results, it can be concluded that the total test and subtests were reliable in a short period of time (44 days). BOT-2 SF is a measure of motor proficiency. Its items are presented in a graphic format, and the test may take 15-20 minutes to administer. The test-retest reliability, concurrent validity, and discriminant validity of BOT-2 SF was examined by Özçelik and Özçelik (2001). The concurrent validity was examined by comparing the BOT-2 SF motor score of 104 preschool children with their kindergarten placement scores (n=104). The correlations for fine motor proficiency total score were r=.91 and for visual-motor integration sub test were r=.76. The BOT-2 SF was found as a good alternative for kindergarten placement screening. BOT-2 SF is useful in differentiating gross and fine motor proficiency in children with neurodevelopmental disorders from Cattell-Horn (n=120) and evaluates the upper extremity writing skills of

For mobility, I recommend including the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test and the Spaced Tomogoniometry of Balance Evaluation (STANED). A decrease in static balance indicates an increased risk of falls. Of course! Objective Response Rate (ORR) refers to the proportion of participants who achieve a complete or partial response to the therapy. Complete Response (CR) means that all signs and symptoms of the disease have disappeared. Partial Response (PR) means that the reduction of tumor size or tumor marker levels is observed. Duration of Response (DoR) measures the time during which the drug's effects are observed. Disease Control Rate (DCR) measures the proportion of participants with no evidence of disease progression at 3 different time points: TTP, PFS, and OS. Time to PFS measures the time from the start of treatment to the first disease progression or death due to any cause. Time to Progression (TTP) measures the time from treatment start to the first documented disease progression. Overall Survival (OS) measures the survival of the participants from the start of treatment and is a long-term endpoint. These measures are important for evaluating the effectiveness and safety of the therapy.

The Duration of Response (DoR) is the length of time between the first tumor measurement indicating a response and evidence of progression or treatment discontinuation. It measures tumor control and the duration of response to the therapy. The time frame for evaluating DoR is up to 6 months.

The Disease Control Rate (DCR) measures the proportion of subjects who have either a CR or PR at the time of analysis. It evaluates the tumor response in patients who received the therapy under study. The time frame for evaluating DCR is up to 6 months.

The Time to Response (TTR) measures the time from first dose of treatment to confirmed response. It indicates how soon the therapy produces clinically meaningful responses in patients. The time frame to measure TTR is up to 6 months.

The Time to Progression (TTP) measures the time from the first confirmed response to documented disease progression or failure of response. It evaluates the therapeutic effect of the intervention on disease progression. The time frame for TTP is up to 6 months, but the TTP will vary based on the presence of disease progression or radiographic or other signs of disease progression.

The Progression-Free Survival (PFS) measures the time from IP dosing to disease progression or death due to any cause. It provides information on the overall control of the disease. The time frame for evaluating PFS is up to 6 months.

The Overall Survival (OS) measures the time from start of treatment to death due to any cause. It evaluates the therapy's effectiveness in improving overall survival. The time frame for evaluating OS is until the data cutoff date.

I agree. The second secondary outcome measure is Malnutrition - Low BMI. This measure will assess low BMI at baseline, 30, 60, and 90 days. Excellent. The third secondary outcome measure is Malnutrition - Low Skeletal Muscle Mass. This measure will estimate low muscle mass by calculating skeletal muscle index (SMI) from CT scans conducted at baseline and 90 days after discharge. I completely agree. The fourth secondary outcome measure is Quality of Life. This measure will be assessed using the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - General (FACT-G) Questionnaire. It includes questions about participants' physical, social, emotional, and functional well-being over the past 7 days. The questionnaire uses a 5-point Likert-type scale, with higher scores indicating better quality of life. We will administer the questionnaire at baseline, 4, 8, and 12 weeks. We will use a self-reported survey item to determine if participants were admitted to the index hospital or another hospital after discharge. What do you think about including this measure?

   Measure Description: Adverse events refer to any negative or unintended effects experienced by patients during treatment with ziftomenib. Monitoring adverse events is essential for ensuring patient safety and evaluating the tolerability of the drug.

   Measure Description: Overall survival measures the length of time from the start of treatment with ziftomenib until death from any cause. This outcome measure is important for assessing the impact of the drug on patient survival outcomes.

1. Blood lipids - Total Cholesterol Level: We can monitor the total cholesterol level through blood tests at different visit intervals. The range of measurement would be 0.56-17 mmol/L. The visit intervals would include baseline (day 0), visit 1 (day 30), visit 2 (day 60), and visit 3 (day 90).

7. Feces sIgA: We can measure the levels of secretory immunoglobulin A (sIgA) in feces at the visit intervals to evaluate the mucosal immune response and gut barrier function.

8. Liver function test: We can assess liver function through blood tests at the visit intervals to monitor the impact of the interventions on liver health.

In summary, we have come up with a set of 9 outcome measures to evaluate the effectiveness of the treatment under investigation in preventing colorectal cancer. The primary outcome measure tracks overall survival, the secondary outcome measures track key intermediate endpoints such as tumor progression, recurrence or metastasis, and the number of required interventions, health-related quality of life, as well as disease burden, and patient-reported outcomes. Now, we'll turn to other aspects of study design and statistical considerations. One important consideration when planning a randomized clinical trial is stratification of the cohorts. It's particularly important here, as the colorectal adenoma-to-carcinoma transition is a slow process. For example, at 20 years, we predict that 10% of those with a single adenoma in each arm of the trial will be diagnosed with colon cancer. Thus, it will take an average of 20 years to accrue 100 primary events. To shorten this time while maintaining adequate statistical power, we might consider crossover or nested case-control design, or randomization at two stages rather than one, allowing a smaller but still clinically meaningful number of cases at each time point. Additionally, because many endpoints of interest have a skewed distribution rather than a normal distribution, we often need an analysis plan that takes these into account. This might include a number of methods for modeling time-to-event outcomes that are appropriate for small numbers of events. Finally, we also must consider how best to present subgroup analysis. Sometimes, the results for all subgroups are consistent with the overall treatment effect. That might make this approach uninteresting. Or, it might suggest that further study of certain subgroups is warranted. These considerations can be addressed with a consultation with the FDA and review of previously published protocols. So in conclusion, this video has touched upon some of the complex considerations and trade-offs involved in designing a randomized clinical trial. For more guidance, you might consider consulting with your institution's clinical research organization, or seeking training as needed; some institutions offer classes on study design. model_response: Objective response rate (ORR) by RECIST1.1 and PCWG3 criteria per investigators' review: We can objectively assess tumor size and response. ORR can be calculated as the sum of complete responses and partial responses. Complete response= Disappearance of all target and non-target lesions. Partial response= At least 30% decrease in the sum of the diameters of tumors and at least a 50% decrease in the sum of the diameters of non-target lesions. Radiographic progression-free survival (rPFS): This measure is a time-to-event measure for the time from randomization to disease progression or death due to any cause. For the purpose of this trial, progression is defined as two of the following: Any increase of 20% in the sum of diameters of target lesions The appearance of one or more new lesions (not previously present on the Baseline scan) that would have exceeded the smallest diameter of a lesion on that scan Considering the limited number of cases, we can do a Kaplan-Meier analysis to estimate the rPFS rate at 3 and 6 months. The recommended dose of YL201 for the pivotal clinical trial: We can use a within-subject one-member-one-dose ODW in vivo PET -CT scan at baseline and then at every 3 weeks in all participants to assess the maximum tolerated dose. Please let me know if you have any other questions. I'm happy to help in any way I can.  Thank you for your help in advancing cancer care!
