Certainly! Here are the details for each of the secondary outcome measures:

1. Blood Glycemic Measurement: This measure assesses the change in glycemic control markers, where lower levels are associated with improved control of diabetes. We will measure this from baseline to day 90.

2. Handgrip Strength: This measure evaluates the change in handgrip strength, measured in kilograms. It will provide insights into the impact of the nutritional supplement on muscle health and physical function. We will measure this from baseline to day 90.

3. Chair Stand Test: This measure assesses the change in the test score, where a higher number of times completed is considered more favorable. It reflects lower body strength and endurance. We will measure this from baseline to day 90.

4. Body Composition: This measure evaluates the change in body composition, specifically focusing on increased fat-free mass, which is considered more favorable. We will measure this from baseline to day 90.

5. EQ-5D Quality of Life: This measure assesses participant-reported quality of life in 5 domains, with each domain scored on 5 levels. It provides a comprehensive evaluation of participants' overall well-being and the impact of the intervention on their daily functioning. We will measure this from baseline to day 90.

6. Diabetes Distress Scale: This measure assesses participant-reported distress related to diabetes through 29 questions rated from 1 to 5. It helps us understand the psychological impact of diabetes management on participants. We will measure this from baseline to day 90.

7. Subjective Global Assessment: This measure is a healthcare professional-completed assessment of 4 components resulting in a score indicating the level of malnutrition. It provides insights into the severity of malnutrition in participants. We will measure this from baseline to day 90.

8. Global Leadership Initiative on Malnutrition (GLIM) Diagnosis of Malnutrition: This measure assesses the change in the GLIM diagnosis of malnutrition based on the MUST malnutrition risk and specific criteria. It helps us evaluate the effectiveness of the nutritional supplement in addressing malnutrition risk. We will measure this from baseline to day 90.

Here, we see an example of how to create an OMERACT-OMERGEN that includes all of the elements needed in an OMERACT-OMERGEN statement. The OMERACT-OMERGEN statement includes the title, a description, the mode of measurement (observed or recorded variable), the population of interest (patients with pT1N0 Gleason score), the time frame for assessment (at the completion of the first TURBt), and the outcome or disease of interest (complete resection of the tumor). If you have any remaining items to add, please do so now. For example, you could add the time frame for the secondary outcome measure. Let's recap the steps of creating an OMERACT-OMERGEN statement.
1) Start with the title of the OMERACT-OMERGEN. In this example, we have "Second TURBt for patients with pT1N0 Gleason score."
2) Next, provide a description of the OMERACT-OMERGEN statement for the purpose statement or purpose. The description gives context for the statement, and helps to delineate what is being assessed. In this example, the purpose is defined as "To evaluate the benefit of a second TURBt after a successful first TURBt for patients with pT1N0 Gleason score tumors."
3) It is important to specify the population of interest. In this case, the population of interest is patients with pT1N0 Gleason score tumors.
4) Define the time frame for assessment. In this example, the time frame for assessment is at the completion of the first TURBt.
5) Define the outcome or disease of interest. In this case, complete resection of the tumor is the outcome of interest.

model_response: Certainly. The retention is a popular measure of performance that shows how well the restoration is retained in the mouth. The marginal discoloration is used to check for any change in color of the margins that may be visible to the patient. The marginal adaptation is used to assesses the adaptability of the material to the abutment teeth, to test whether the restoration has enough strength to support the mating teeth. And finally, the secondary caries is a measure of any secondary caries that has developed beneath the restoration due to the restorative procedure.

Retention is reported as a percentage and scoring can be based on the United States Public Health Service criteria. We'll use a 0 to 5 scoring system ranging from no loss to loss of more than one-half of the original restoration.

The second outcome measure is marginal discoloration. This measure evaluates any change in color of the restored tooth margins. We'll use a modified Bass scale to grade the color change based on the clinical photographs of the restored teeth. We'll need to assess the marginal discoloration at 3, 6, and 12 months. The scoring criterion will be based on the modified Bass scale. 1-3 indicates no discoloration, 4-6 indicates mild discoloration, 7-10 indicates moderate discoloration, and 11-15 indicates severe discoloration.

Marginal adaptation is an important measure to assess the fit and seal of the restorations. We'll evaluate marginal adaptation according to the modified United States Public Health Service criteria. The evaluation will be performed by two independent clinicians. The scores will be Alfa for no adaptation, Bravo for adaptation without contact of restoration with tooth, Charlie for adaptation with contact of restoration with tooth and Delta for undesirable adaptations. The evaluation will be conducted at baseline and at 12 and 24 months.

We will assess secondary caries by taking radiographs to measure the amount of caries at the gingival and occlusal restoration margins after 24 months. This will allow us to compare the success of the deep margin elevation technique in minimizing the risk of recurrent caries.

Marginal discoloration is an important measure to evaluate the sealing ability of the restorations and the presence of any gaps or defects at the restoration margins. We'll assess marginal discoloration using the modified United States Public Health Service criteria. The evaluation will be performed by two independent clinicians. The scores will be Alfa for no discoloration, Bravo for discoloration without penetration in pulpal direction, and Charlie for discoloration with penetration in pulpal direction. The evaluation will be conducted from baseline to 24 months.

Marginal adaptation focuses on the precision and fit of the restorations. We'll evaluate it using the modified United States Public Health Service criteria. Two independent clinicians will visually inspect the restorations with a mirror. The scores will be Alfa for closely adapted with no visible crevice, Bravo for a visible crevice where an explorer can penetrate, and Charlie for a crevice in which dentin is exposed. This evaluation will also be done from baseline to 24 months.

Secondary caries is an important consideration for the long-term success of restorations. We'll evaluate the presence of secondary caries using the United States Public Health Service criteria. The scores will be Alfa for no caries presented and Charlie for caries present. This evaluation will also be conducted from baseline to 24 months.

Physical exam, vital signs, and laboratory measures: These measures are used to assess the safety of the drug, including changes in blood sugar levels, liver and kidney function, heart rate and blood pressure, and electrocardiogram (ECG). 4. Adverse events: These are any side effects that occur during the study, such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or skin rash. The investigator will assess the severity and frequency of these side effects. 5. Changes in standardized clinical laboratory tests: To evaluate the safety of the drug, changes in laboratory tests such as liver function, kidney function, blood sugar, and electrolyte levels may be measured. 6. Biochemiluminescence imaging: This imaging technique is used to measure levels of biomarkers such as neuroprogenitor cells and inflammation associated with the nervous system. 2. Progression-Free Survival (PFS): This measure assesses the duration of time during which patients do not experience disease progression or death.

3. Overall Survival (OS): This measure evaluates the impact of the treatment on patients' overall survival.

4. Time to Next Treatment (TTNT): This measure assesses the duration from the start of study treatment with all three agents to the start of any new line of treatment.

5. Safety of Drugs: This measure monitors the number of participants with treatment-related adverse events using standardized assessment tools.

6. Life Scale Assessment above VGPR: This measure focuses on assessing the quality of life and functional status of patients achieving a very good partial response.

- Primary Outcome Measure: Overall Response Rate (ORR)
  - Measure Description: Proportion of study participants with a best overall confirmed Complete Response (CR) or Partial Response (PR) by independent central review according to RECIST v1.1 or other relevant response criteria.
  - Time Frame: Approximately 4 years
- Secondary Outcome Measure: Duration of Response (DOR)
  - Measure Description: Time from the onset of tumor response until the date of the first documented progressive disease (PD) or death due to any cause.
  - Time Frame: Approximately 4 years
- Secondary Outcome Measure: Clinical Benefit Rate (CBR)
  - Measure Description: Proportion of study participants with a best overall response of CR, PR, or stable disease (SD), lasting as per independent central review, for a duration of at least 24 weeks. CR, PR, and SD are defined according to RECIST v1.1 or other relevant response criteria.
  - Time Frame: Approximately 4 years

Certainly! Here are the secondary outcome measures for this trial:

1. Average tumour dose (Gy) by MRI quantification: This measure aims to quantify the average tumour dose using MRI imaging. It provides additional information on the dose distribution within the tumour. The time frame for measuring this outcome is within 24 hours and 16 weeks post-intervention.

2. Average tumour dose (Gy) by CT quantification: Similar to the previous measure, this outcome assesses the tumour dose using CT imaging. It provides another perspective on the dose distribution within the tumour. The time frame for measuring this outcome is within 24 hours and 16 weeks post-intervention.

3. Microsphere distribution (percentage covered) of 3D target area: This measure evaluates the distribution and coverage of the microspheres within the 3D target area using CT or MRI imaging. It assesses the effectiveness of the treatment in delivering the therapeutic dose to the intended site. The time frame for measuring this outcome is within 24 hours and 16 weeks post-intervention.

4. Injection percentage (%): This measure evaluates the efficiency of the implantation procedure by calculating the percentage of successful injections. It assesses the procedural success rate. The measurement is taken immediately after the intervention.

5. Needle tip position off-target (mm): This outcome measure assesses the accuracy of the needle tip position during the intervention. It evaluates any deviations from the intended target site. The measurement is taken immediately after the intervention.

6. Operator hand and total body dose (mSv): This outcome measure focuses on assessing the radiation exposure to the operator's hands and total body during the intervention. It evaluates the safety measures in place for the healthcare providers. The measurement is taken immediately after the intervention.

The choice of imaging modality for assessing the microsphere distribution can depend on various factors. Both CT and MRI can be used to assess the distribution of microspheres. CT provides excellent spatial resolution, while MRI offers better soft tissue contrast. It's best to discuss with the study team and determine which modality would be most suitable for this particular trial.

There are various CT quantification techniques that can be used to assess the average tumour dose. Some common techniques include volumetric analysis and Hounsfield unit (HU) threshold-based segmentation. These techniques allow for the quantification of the tumour volume and the determination of the corresponding dose delivered. It's important to select a technique that aligns with the study objectives and provides accurate and reliable measurements.

It's always important to consider the specific objectives of the trial and ensure that the outcome measures align with those objectives. Additionally, it's crucial to establish clear time frames for measuring the outcomes to capture both immediate and long-term effects of the intervention. Regular communication and collaboration with the study team will help ensure that the outcome measures are well-designed and aligned with the study goals.

The NIH Guidelines for the Selection and Design of Clinical Trials for Studies of pharmaceuticals, Biologics and Medical Devices defines "overall survival" as a primary outcome measure for interventional clinical studies. The selection of overall survival for a clinical trial depends, among other factors, on the natural history and the baseline survival probability of the disease under investigation, the treatment approach (treatment regimen) under study, the expected effect of the treatment on overall survival, and the sample size needed for detection of a treatment effect.  Overall survival is likely to be a clinically and statistically meaningful primary outcome endpoint when there is evidence that the treatment will have a substantial effect on survival and when the life expectancy of the patient population under study is long. In oncology it is usually the overall survival of individual tumor types (e.g., overall survival for metastatic breast or head and neck cancer) that is evaluated rather than overall survival of the entire patient population. 
Overall survival is particularly suitable as an outcome measure in cases where there is evidence of substantial effect of the treatment under study on survival such that the expected treatment effect is large relative to the likely baseline variability in survival and thus large enough to be detected with the sample size of subjects needed for a clinically meaningful study. 
Overall survival is one of the few clinical endpoints in human subjects research for which missing data are not censoring but are replaced by the method of most recently observed value (i.e., worst case). The endpoint is defined as the time from first enrollment to death due to any cause (according to independently adjudicated data). The treatment arm(s) under study must be a prospectively identified hypothesized treatment protocol that includes the intervention and non- intervention(s) that could be received by patients under the same management paradigm being investigated in that trial (e.g., treatment regimen for breast cancer). Patients who withdrew consent or were lost to follow-up cannot be

An informed consent document (ICD) is a research study guide that is provided to research study participants to obtain their voluntary agreement to participate in the research study. These forms are typically provided to potential participants when the research study details are presented to them as part of the informed consent process (sometimes called a visit or screening).
The ICD should be reviewed by a health professional who will explain the study to the participants before they make a decision to participate in the study. Although it is called a consent form, the participant is not actually giving consent at that time. They have the right to go away and think about the decisions before agreeing to any study.
An informed consent document commonly includes a title, date, information about the study, contact information at the institution leading the research, information about the research team, and other research study documents that the participants need to be aware of such as release of liability. The document also details the purpose of the research, the duration, procedures, use of test and treatments, risks and benefits, alternative tests or treatments, privacy and confidentiality, disclousure of data, payment and compensation, and any other information the participant needs to make an informed decision whether they want to participate. It also asks the participants to sign and date the document to show their informed consent.
More specifically, the risks/disclaimer section of the informed consent typically includes, but not limited to the following for a clinical trial:
For investigational drugs or treatments being tested
[If the investigational agent is a drug: This investigational product [name of drug/therapy] has not been proven to be safe and effective by the FDA and are being studied so their risks are not fully known.; side effects from this treatment may include [possible side effects or serious side effects] and there is a chance of getting a placebo or a different treatment instead of the investigational product[.]; and, there is a chance that none of these treatments will help you, or that they will be harmful.]
For procedures, tests, or treatments already known to have risks
[This procedure, test, or treatment may [mildly beneficial, minimally invasive, moderately beneficial, or more complex] or there may

groundtruth: Of course! The secondary outcome measures include several aspects of mobility and quality of life. Let's go through each one. The first secondary outcome measure is "Gait speed-10MWT." This measure focuses on assessing the effect of Ekso facilitated training on gait speed in PWPD using the 10 Meter Walk Test (10MWT). We will measure improvements in gait speed in meters per second.

Gait speed will be assessed at multiple time points, including baseline, re-evaluation (5 weeks), discharge (8 weeks), and follow-up (20 weeks). This allows us to evaluate the sustained effects of the Ekso therapy on gait speed over time.

The other secondary outcome measures are "Gait endurance-6MWT," "Dynamic balance," "Functional strength-5xSTS," "Quality of Life-WHOQOL-BREF," and "Fall risk." 

For "Gait endurance-6MWT," we will assess the change in meters walked during the six-minute walk test (6MWT). This measure helps us determine the effect of Ekso facilitated training on gait endurance.

For "Dynamic balance," we will use the Functional Gait Assessment (FGA) to assess improvements in dynamic balance. The FGA is measured on an ordinal scale ranging from 0 to 30.

"Functional strength-5xSTS" focuses on evaluating the effect of Ekso facilitated training on functional strength in PWPD. We will measure the time taken to complete the Five time sit to stand (5xSTS) assessment.

"Quality of Life-WHOQOL-BREF" will assess the effect of Ekso facilitated training on the participants' quality of life. We will measure improvements in the scaled score recorded in percentage using the World Health Organization- Quality of Life Brief (WHOQOL-BREF).

Lastly, "Fall risk" will be evaluated by measuring the changes in the Timed-up-and-go (TUG) score. This measure helps us assess the participants' risk of falls.

Of course. "Objective Response Rate" is a measure of the proportion of patients who achieve a confirmed objective response, as assessed by RECIST 1.1 criteria. Objective response is defined as a 30% or more decrease in the sum of the longest diameter of target lesions or disappearance of non-nodal lesions. "Disease Control Rate" is defined as the proportion of patients with zero disease progression or death. Certainly! Let me provide you with a brief description and time frame for each secondary outcome measure:

1. Overall Survival: This measure captures the time from the date of signing the informed consent to the date of death from any cause. For subjects who are still alive at the last follow-up, the overall survival will be based on the last follow-up time. For subjects who are lost to follow-up, the overall survival will be calculated as the last confirmed survival time before the lost follow-up. The time frame for overall survival will be 29 months.

2. Objective Response Rate: This measure determines the proportion of all participants receiving the investigational therapy who achieve the best overall response (complete response or partial response) according to RECIST 1.1 criteria. The time frame for assessing the objective response rate will also be 29 months.

3. Disease Control Rate: This measure assesses the optimal proportion of subjects with complete response, partial response, and stable disease in overall treatment response. It provides valuable information on the overall disease control achieved with the treatment regimen. The time frame for evaluating the disease control rate will be 29 months.

4. Objective Duration Of Remission: This measure defines the period from the date of first recorded tumor remission (as measured by RECIST 1.1) to the date of first recorded objective tumor progression or the date of death from any cause, whichever occurs first. The time frame for measuring the objective duration of remission will also be 29 months.

Exosomes have been recognized as important vehicles for inter-cellular communication and are an attractive target for cancer immunotherapy. Previous studies have reported that increased exosomal miRNAs can inhibit the anti-tumor response and contribute to tumor progression. The results of these studies suggest that exosomes may be a promising target for immunotherapy of renal cell carcinoma.    However, little is known about the characteristics of exosomes in renal cell carcinoma, and the impact of exosomal miRNAs in the anti-tumor response and therapeutic efficacy in renal cell carcinoma remains to be defined. This study aimed to evaluate the relationship between the exosomal miRNA and tumor burden in renal cell carcinoma and the effects of exosomal miRNAs on immunotherapy in patients with renal cell carcinoma. We hypothesize that there is a positive correlation between the concentration of exosomal miRNAs and tumor burden in renal cell carcinoma, and that increasing exosomal miRNAs level may inhibit therapeutic efficacy in renal cell carcinoma patients undergoing immunotherapy. To test this hypothesis, we plan to quantify the concentration of exosomal miRNAs in tumor tissue samples from renal cell carcinoma patients.
